stem: A 40-year-old client with a T3 spinal cord injury (SCI) is undergoing a scheduled bed change. Suddenly, their BP rises and they begin to shiver. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: At 14:30, a 40-year-old client with quadriplegia experienced a severe hypertensive spike during a scheduled bed change. The client is shivering.
Background: The client has a complete T3 level SCI and self-catheterizes. The bladder was recently emptied.
Assessment: The client's BP is 210/118, HR is 52, and RR is 24. The client reports blurred vision and is extremely flushed on their face and chest. Skin assessment reveals a Stage 2 pressure injury on the sacral region and compression socks rolled tight.
Recommendation: Immediately elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees and inspect for non-urological triggers, such as skin pressure or tight clothing. Monitor BP and heart rate closely.

actionOptions.text: Immediately elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees.
Remove the restrictive socks and alleviate pressure on the sacral sore.
Instruct the client to cough vigorously to lower the BP.
Administer STAT IV Epinephrine to increase the heart rate.

parameterOptions.text: Frequent blood pressure and heart rate monitoring.
Visual changes and presence of a pounding headache.
Presence of a positive Babinski sign.

rationale.correct: The client is most likely experiencing Autonomic Dysreflexia (AD) triggered by noxious stimuli related to skin breakdown and tight socks. Even though the bladder is empty, any painful or irritating stimulus below the level of the injury (T3) can cause a sympathetic surge. The priority is to elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees (a1) to immediately lower the blood pressure. The next priority is to remove the triggering stimuli (a2) by loosening the socks and alleviating pressure on the sacral sore. Parameters to monitor include frequent blood pressure and heart rate monitoring (p1) to assess the effectiveness of interventions and neurological symptoms such as visual changes and headache (p2) indicating the severity of the hypertensive crisis.
clinicalPearls: While a full bladder is a common trigger of AD, tight clothing, shoes, or pressure sores are also major contributors.
A 'pounding headache' is a classic subjective symptom of a dangerous AD spike.
Always loosen any tight clothing or straps if AD is suspected.

questionTrap.trap: Calling the provider before sitting the patient up.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Sitting the patient up (90 degrees) IS the treatment. If you wait to call the provider while the patient is flat, they might have a hemorrhagic stroke from the 210/118 pressure. Sit them up immediately, then call the provider.
